title: Prepare NFS and PostgreSQL servers
content:
Before installing OO, perform the following tasks:

  1. Prepare NFS and PostgreSQL servers
  2. Decide the load balancer option 

Prepare NFS and PostgreSQL servers 

Use a separate NFS and PostgreSQL server for OO, instead of using the same servers as for Service Management or Cloud Management.

Before you begin, prepare separate servers for OO installation:

  • Decide on the hardware resources (worker nodes, NFS server, and PostgreSQL server) that are required for your OO deployment. For details, see the Service Management or Cloud Management sizing guide.
  • Prepare a separate NFS server and separate PostgreSQL database server, and required worker nodes for OO, according to your OO sizing profile.

Decide the load balancer option

Before deploying OO Containerized in a cluster along with Service Management, decide how to access the OO system. You can either:

  • Use the same FQDN but different ports: OO shares the same FQDN with Service Management but uses a different port. For example, xxx.example.com:443 for Service Management, and xxx.example.com:9443 for OO. With this option, OO can leverage the load balancer used by Service Management, and hence requires no additional load balancer; however, you must expose the OO service on a port other than 443 in the load balancer.
  • Use different FQDNs but the same port: OO uses a different FQDN than Service Management but the same port 443. For example, sma.example.com:443 for Service Management, and oo.example.com:443 for OO. With this option, to use port 443 for both Service Management and OO, you must configure a separate load balancer for OO, instead of sharing the Service Management one.
